awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unfolding the Link between Forest Canopy Structure and Flow Morphology: A Physics-based Representation for Numerical Weather Prediction Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerical weather prediction models are becoming indispensable for severe weather and air quality forecasts as well as for managements in river flows, wind energy, agriculture, and food security. Model results of near-surface weather parameters are routinely supplied to end-users either directly or with statistical post-processing. To produce more reliable numerical weather predictions, two main issues must be addressed: (i) numerical resolution and (ii) representation of the near-surface conditions that shape the local-weather. While advances in computation are enabling a better representation of real world conditions in numerical weather prediction models, representing the detailed vegetated canopy-atmosphere interactions remains a challenge. This is partially the result of canopy heterogeneities present at different scales whose variability significantly affects the near-surface region of the atmosphere. This near-surface region is host to a myriad of relevant meteorological processes such as fog, frost, dew, and turbulence in general, which if not accounted for, can distort weather forecasts. To tackle this limitation of current numerical weather prediction models, the focus of this research project is on understanding and quantifying the effect of vegetated canopy heterogeneities and developing new methodologies to properly account for them within numerical weather prediction models. This will be achieved through the synergy of wind tunnel measurements and high-resolution numerical simulations. With the acquired data, new canopy representations will be formulated that expand upon traditional relationships currently used in numerical weather prediction models such that the spatiotemporal variability of the flow in vegetated canopies can be well captured. 


This research project will improve the understanding and representation of the canopy-atmosphere interactions on a heterogeneous canopy cover. A better representation of canopies within numerical weather prediction models will lead to more accurate weather forecasts. This research project also provides learning experiences to graduate students and involves underrepresented undergraduate students in the STEM fields. The PIs lay out a plan that involves collaborations with the REFUGES program at University of Utah to increase the number of underrepresented minorities in academia.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to address the need to understand, characterize, and model Atmospheric Surface Layer processes over surfaces characterized by heterogeneous distributions of vegetated canopies, to improve their representation in Numerical Weather Prediction models. To achieve this goal, the proposed project had three main objectives: 1) Relate the momentum fluxes induced by the heterogeneous vegetated canopies to the spatial structure of the canopies. We hypothesized that the canopy spatial heterogeneity should be reflected in the mean momentum flux under certain flow conditions, and hence should be added as a correction term to the traditional homogeneous canopy relations. 2) Develop a new framework that would facilitate the inclusion of the canopy effects on the mean momentum transport in numerical weather prediction models. 3) Formulate new relations or corrections that account for the canopy spatial heterogeneity effects on the flow.

Results from this research have led to two main results: 1. The generalization of traditional turbulence flux scaling relations that are of broad and continued use by the atmospheric science community, and are present in every numerical weather prediction and climate model. These scaling relations where initially developed more than fifty years ago by Profs. Monin and Obukhov for statistically stationary, and homogeneous flow conditions, in absence of subsidence. However, they are commonly used to represent land-atmosphere interactions in complex situations as well due to the absence of alternative solutions. Our results suggest that by including the metric of turbulence anisotropy as an additional non-dimensional variable in developing scaling relations, it is possible to generalize these traditional scaling relations to all flow conditions, regardless of complexity. Therefore, we have demonstrated that this approach provides a path forward in generalizing scaling relations to all complex flow conditions.  2. The effect of heterogeneous complex surfaces is not limited to additional perturbations on the turbulent exchanges between the land surface and the atmosphere, but these also often produce mean advective fluxes that have been traditionally neglected. Our work, has pushed to emphasize the relevance of these processes and has provided a revised framework on how to include these contributions in numerical weather prediction models.

In terms of broader impact, this project has directly funded one PhD student who is about to graduate, and it has also facilitated co-advising three other graduate students. Despite the many challenges faced with COVID over the past two years, one of the graduate students was able to participate in the University of Utah STEM Ambassador Program training. In this program students are trained how to design, implement, and evaluate innovative public engagement events that promote an open-minded exchange of ideas between scientists and diverse members of the public. As part of the training, the student also prepares and delivers the designed outreach activity to the community of interest. In addition, as a result of this project, we have been able to established very productive international synergies with research groups in Austria, and Germany which have led to join publications and new research proposals.
